description.narrative:
BBC Media Action har ansökt om 21,685,500 SEK från Sida för att kunna genomföra projektet ”Tikambe Re-Loaded Project” i Zambia (Lusaka, Centrala, Kopparbältet och Norra provinsen) under perioden 2017-2020. Insatsen syftar till att förbättra ungas tillgänglighet till SRHR-information samt tillhandahålla, tillgängliggöra och öka upptaget av SRH-tjänster riktade mot unga. På grund av unga människors begränsade tillgång till SRHR-information- och tjänster är denna grupp sårbar i relation till ett antal risker, såsom sexuellt överförbara sjukdomar, HIV och oönskade graviditeter, något som denna insats avser adressera.
Projektets budget är 21,685,500 SEK, Sida finansierar hela beloppet.

BBC Media Action has applied to Sida for funding of 21,685,500 SEK to carry out the "Tikambe Re-Loaded Project” in Zambia (Lusaka, Central, Copperbelt and Northern provinces) during the period 2017-2020. The intervention aims at improving access to SRHR information for young people as well as the provision, access and uptake of youth-friendly SRHR services. It is intended to address limited SRHR information and services for young people which leave young people exposed to numerous risks in terms of sexually transmitted infections, HIV and unwanted pregnancies.
The intervention’s total budget is 21,685,500 SEK, Sida will fund the entire budget.

description.narrative: During the period under review progress has been made towards the goal of reducing the vulnerability of young people (between the ages of 11 and 24) to sexual and reproductive health risks. Some of the key results are here presented by outcome. Young people are better equipped to make informed choices on their SRHR through provision of accurate and accessible information by, for and with young people and a more supportive environment. - The panel study shows that on a number of variables, such as intended condom usage, those exposed were reporting adopting healthier SRH behaviours, were more likely to have accurate SRH knowledge and were more likely to feel supported by key people in their lives such as teachers on their SRHR. They were also more likely to think females should make decisions on matters such as contraception and when to engage in sex. Those who had been exposed to Tikambe were more likely to say that they were more likely to use condoms in the future, to use modern contraceptives, and to talk to their partners on the prevention of pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases. There were no signigicant variations by gender. - In terms of demonstrating accurate knowledge on SRHR, overall, those exposed to Tikambe exhibited having accurate knowledge to enable them to make informed choices such as knowing about HIV, how you can tell if someone is HIV positive and how you can protect yourself from getting STIs. - Young people exposed to Tikambe felt more supported on their SRHR by teachers, health centres and their family. - In terms of women and girls participation in decision-making in SRHR issues, the panel findings suggest that those exposed to Tikambe were less likely to think that men should make the decisions in relationships and were more likely to think females should, particularly on such important issues as contraception, which generally have more of an impact on the girl. The provision, access and uptake of youth friendly SRH services is improved - 28 youth-friendly SRH services were better equipped to provide services to young people. This was through training of the staff, support from Restless Development young leaders, provision of tents to create a private space for young people and sharing of information and resources. - Referrals are key in ensuring young people access services that might not be provided in the school or clinic. 2,400 in school (Male 888, Female 1,512) and 1,560 out of school young people (Male 624, Female 936) were referred to health facilities through project interventions in the year under review. Health facilities responded and completed 560 referral cases received from the schools. - Young people reported that they received adequate guidance and counselling services in schools on issues around the re-entry policy, avoiding teenage pregnancies and making informed choices on sex. - In terms of improvements in SRH services, health providers reported improvements in a number of areas including setting of monthly targets, establishment and/or revamping of youth friendly spaces, data capturing and management, implementing health education promotion campaigns/outreach events as well as coordination among service providers. - Improvements in SRH service provision were observed. For instance, the Kasama District Health office acted on the recommendation made by the young people to increase youth friendly spaces by procuring 10 tents used as mobile youth friendly spaces. In Lusaka, (Matero) a civic leader authorized the use of the community hall as a youth friendly space by the clinic to meet the increasing demand of youth SRHR services.This was based on the recommendations by young people and commitments made by decision-makers to act on the issues raised in the position papers or assessments to improve SRH service provision.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
